sn12.70:4.2: Ānanda, this one time I was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn12.70:4.3: Now at that time the Buddha was honored, respected, esteemed, revered, and venerated. And he received robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
sn12.70:4.4: And the mendicant Saṅgha was also honored, respected, esteemed, revered, and venerated. And they received robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
sn12.70:4.5: But the wanderers who followed other paths were not honored, respected, esteemed, revered, and venerated. And they didn’t receive robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
sn12.70:5.1: Now at that time the wanderer Susīma was residing at Rājagaha together with a large community of wanderers.
sn12.70:5.2: Then his community said to Susīma:
sn12.70:5.3: “Reverend Susīma, please live the spiritual life with the ascetic Gotama.
sn12.70:5.4: Memorize that teaching and have us recite it with you.
sn12.70:5.5: When we’ve memorized it we’ll recite it to the laity.
sn12.70:5.6: In this way we too will be honored, respected, esteemed, revered, and venerated. And we’ll receive robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”
sn12.70:5.7: “Yes, reverends,” replied Susīma. Then he went to Venerable Ānanda,
sn12.70:5.9: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn12.70:5.11: “Reverend Ānanda, I wish to live the spiritual life in this teaching and training.”
sn12.70:6.1: Then Ānanda took Susīma to the Buddha,
sn12.70:6.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn12.70:6.5: he wishes to live the spiritual life in this teaching and training.”
sn12.70:6.6: “Well then, Ānanda, give Susīma the going forth.”
sn12.70:6.7: And the wanderer Susīma received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
sn12.70:7.1: Now at that time several mendicants had declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence:
sn12.70:7.2: “We understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn12.70:7.6: He went up to those mendicants,
sn12.70:7.8: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
sn12.70:7.10: “Is it really true that the venerables have declared enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence?”
sn12.70:8.1: “But knowing and seeing thus, do you wield the many kinds of psychic powers?
sn12.70:8.2: That is, multiplying yourselves and becoming one again;
sn12.70:8.3: going unimpeded through a wall, an embankment, or a mountain as if through space;
sn12.70:8.4: diving in and out of the earth as if it was water;
sn12.70:8.5: walking on water as if it was earth;
sn12.70:8.6: flying cross-legged through the air like a bird;
sn12.70:8.7: touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. Do you control the body as far as the Brahmā realm?”
sn12.70:9.1: “Well, knowing and seeing thus do you, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far?”
sn12.70:10.1: “Well, knowing and seeing thus, do you understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with your mind?
sn12.70:10.2: Do you understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’, and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’?
sn12.70:10.4: Do you understand mind with hate as ‘mind with hate’, and mind without hate as ‘mind without hate’?
sn12.70:10.6: Do you understand mind with delusion as ‘mind with delusion’, and mind without delusion as ‘mind without delusion’?
sn12.70:10.8: Do you understand contracted mind as ‘contracted mind’, and scattered mind as ‘scattered mind’?
sn12.70:10.10: Do you understand expansive mind as ‘expansive mind’, and unexpansive mind as ‘unexpansive mind’?
sn12.70:10.12: Do you understand mind that is not supreme as ‘mind that is not supreme’, and mind that is supreme as ‘mind that is supreme’?
sn12.70:10.14: Do you understand mind unified in samādhi as ‘mind unified in samādhi’, and mind not unified in samādhi as ‘mind not unified in samādhi’?
sn12.70:10.16: Do you understand freed mind as ‘freed mind’, and unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’?”
sn12.70:11.1: “Well, knowing and seeing thus, do you recollect many kinds of past lives, that is,
sn12.70:11.2: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand lives; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world evolving, many eons of the world contracting and evolving? Do you remember:
sn12.70:11.3: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else.
sn12.70:11.4: There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’
sn12.70:11.5: Do you so recollect your many kinds of past lives, with features and details?”
sn12.70:12.1: “Well, knowing and seeing thus, do you, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds?
sn12.70:12.2: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
sn12.70:12.3: These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, do you see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. And do you understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds?”
sn12.70:13.1: “Well, knowing and seeing thus, do you have direct meditative experience of the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form?”
sn12.70:14.1: “Well now, venerables, how could there be such a declaration when these things are not attained?”
sn12.70:14.3: “Reverend Susīma, we are freed by wisdom.”
sn12.70:15.1: “I don’t understand the detailed meaning of what you have said in brief.
sn12.70:15.2: Please teach me this matter so I can understand the detailed meaning.”
sn12.70:15.3: “Reverend Susīma, whether you understand or not, we are freed by wisdom.”
sn12.70:16.1: Then Susīma went to the Buddha,
sn12.70:16.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn12.70:16.3: and informed the Buddha of all he had discussed with those mendicants.
sn12.70:16.4: “Susīma, first comes knowledge of the stability of natural principles. Afterwards there is knowledge of extinguishment.”
sn12.70:17.1: “Sir, I don’t understand the detailed meaning of what you have said in brief.
sn12.70:17.2: Please teach me this matter so I can understand the detailed meaning.”
sn12.70:17.3: “Reverend Susīma, whether you understand or not, first comes knowledge of the stability of natural principles. Afterwards there is knowledge of extinguishment.
sn12.70:18.1: What do you think, Susīma? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn12.70:18.3: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn12.70:18.5: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn12.70:18.6: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn12.70:18.10: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn12.70:18.12: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn12.70:18.13: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn12.70:18.19: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
sn12.70:18.21: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
sn12.70:18.22: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn12.70:18.26: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn12.70:18.28: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn12.70:18.29: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn12.70:19.1: “So, Susīma, you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn12.70:19.3: You should truly see any kind of feeling at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all feeling—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn12.70:19.5: You should truly see any kind of perception at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all perception—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn12.70:19.6: You should truly see any kind of choices at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all choices—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn12.70:19.8: You should truly see any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with proper wisdom: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn12.70:20.1: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
sn12.70:20.2: Being disillusioned they become dispassionate. Being dispassionate they’re freed. When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn12.70:20.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
sn12.70:21.1: Susīma, do you see that rebirth is a condition for old age and death?”
sn12.70:21.3: “Do you see that future existence is a condition for rebirth?”
sn12.70:21.5: “Do you see that grasping is a condition for future existence?”
sn12.70:21.7: “Do you see that craving is a condition for grasping?”
sn12.70:21.9: “Do you see that feeling is a condition for craving …
sn12.70:21.10: contact is a condition for feeling …
sn12.70:21.11: the six sense fields are conditions for contact …
sn12.70:21.12: name and form is a condition for the six sense fields …
sn12.70:21.13: consciousness is a condition for name and form …
sn12.70:21.14: choices are a condition for consciousness …
sn12.70:21.15: ignorance is a condition for choices?”
sn12.70:22.1: “Do you see that when rebirth ceases old age and death cease?”
sn12.70:22.3: “Do you see that when future existence ceases rebirth ceases?”
sn12.70:22.5: “Do you see that when grasping ceases future existence ceases …
sn12.70:22.9: when the six sense fields cease, contact ceases …
sn12.70:22.10: when name and form cease, the six sense fields cease …
sn12.70:22.11: when consciousness ceases name and form ceases …

sn12.70:29.1: “Well now, Susīma, how could there be such a declaration when these things are not attained?”
sn12.70:30.1: Then Venerable Susīma bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet and said:
sn12.70:30.2: “I have made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me to go forth as a thief in such a well-explained teaching and training.
sn12.70:30.3: Please, sir, accept my mistake for what it is, so I will restrain myself in future.”
sn12.70:31.1: “Indeed, Susīma, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to go forth as a thief in such a well-explained teaching and training.
sn12.70:31.2: Suppose they arrest a bandit, a criminal and show him to the king, saying:
sn12.70:31.3: ‘Your Majesty, this is a bandit, a criminal. Punish him as you will.’
sn12.70:31.5: ‘Go, my men, and tie this man’s arms tightly behind his back with a strong rope. Shave his head and march him from street to street and from square to square to the beating of a harsh drum. Then take him out the south gate and there, to the south of the city, chop off his head.’
sn12.70:31.6: The king’s men would do as they were told.
sn12.70:31.7: What do you think, Susīma? Wouldn’t that man experience pain and distress because of that?”
sn12.70:32.1: “Although that man would experience pain and distress because of that,
sn12.70:32.2: going forth as a thief in such a well-explained teaching and training has a more painful and bitter result. And it even leads to the underworld.
sn12.70:32.3: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
sn12.70:32.4: For it is growth in the training of the noble one to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”
